text: (upbeat music)
Yeah first, I'd like to thank c&en
for giving me the chance to be part of the Talented Twelve.
And for everyone who wrote the really nice articles,
and organizing this really nice symposium.
And also I'd like to congratulate everyone else
in the Talented Twelve.
As the baby of this group,
I am super-duper humbled to be amongst all of you.
So first I'm gonna give you a little bit
of background about me.
So, I was born in Maryland
to two Ghanaian-American immigrants,
and I spent my first two years there.
At the age of two, I moved to Ghana,
where my parents are from,
and lived there for 10 years.
That was a great experience.
I got to learn about my culture.
I learned my language.
I had the privilege of attending a really nice,
a really great school
that really gave me a good background in math sciences,
and also really got to, essentially
gain a lot of interest in certain things
that I didn't realize would shape my future,
including chemical biology.
I then moved to Virginia,
and attended middle school and high school,
here in Virginia.
And there you could find me either on the tennis court
or I also gained a really nice interest
in math and science.
While I'd, you know, get things marked wrong
for spelling it the British way.
Math and science is the same everywhere
and that's great.
So after high school,
because of my interest in science,
I went to Cornell University,
and I'd often kinda teeter-totter
between whether I wanted to be a chemistry major,
a biology major.
We didn't quite have a chemical biology focus at that time.
I ended up being a chem major
and took a lot of biology classes.
And I think my interest has kinda stayed that path since.
Outside of coursework,
I actually first joined a lab just for work study.
I figured I was science major,
I might as well join a lab,
and see what that's about.
I started off in a microbiology lab first washing dishes
of course, as often many of us do,
and then moved on
to actually performing some really nice gene mapping
in this ciliate here.
And then halfway through my undergraduate career,
I met Manuel Aregulian
who was doing some really interesting work
with plant biology, specifically, medicinal plant biology.
And I feel like anyone who has
like a maybe African background
has always like a grandma
who has some plant that does something,
and I thought that was super interesting
to bring kinda science to that.
So I spent a summer in the Dominican Republic
studying medicinal plants,
and then came back to Cornell
and then studied solidago canadensis
which was thought to have some
anti-diabetic therapeutic potential.
After this, I definitely loved research a lot more
than I thought I did.
And I wasn't entirely sure what to do
after undergraduate,
my undergraduate career.
So I decided to participate in a PREP program.
So the PREP programs are funded by the NIH.
And they are specifically
for underrepresented minorities in science.
And there are a number of institutions.
I performed mine at Mount Sinai in New York City.
There, I was mentored outside the lab by Terry Krulwich,
who was an amazing scientist and an amazing mentor.
And she was really,
she was really important for me in helping me
kind of craft a graduate school application,
which I didn't really have much experience with
or have family who really knew anything about.
So she was really important to me in that regard.
And in terms of research while I was there,
I took a slight turn off,
and did some homology modeling and virtual screening.
I didn't have any background at all
in any type of computational work,
yet Abner took me on,
and he thought it'd be cool for me to also learn about this.
So I spent the first six months of my year there
kind of learning homology modeling,
learning the scripts behind that.
And then for my last six months,
Abner kind of put me in a lot of collaborations
with different scientists,
which one, exposed me to a lot of science,
and two, helped me learn how to kind of craft a story
for a publication.
And it ended up in two nice publications
with a couple of collaborators,
which was great.
I then decided to pursue a PhD,
after my great experience at Mount Sinai.
Luckily I got into a number of programs,
and decided to choose Yale's pharmacology program
due to number of reasons,
including some really cool programs they had,
such as the medical research scholars program,
which kind of helped bridge the gap
between the bench and medicine.
And also because of their really strong chemical biology,
you know, labs that they had.
Specifically, you know, the work of Craig Crews.
So I actually for the first time met Craig
during, essentially rotation talks
where each professor is given five minutes to kind of,
to sell their work to incoming grad students
for possible rotation.
And when I heard Craig talk,
I just could not stop smiling.
I thought the work was so, so cool.
And luckily I ended up rotating and joining the lab.
So what was so cool about Craig's work,
first, I'm going to take a few steps back
to just telling you about the life of a protein.
So as many of you probably know,
DNA is transcribed into RNA,
which is translated into proteins.
And proteins then go on to perform
their intended function.
Once a protein's performed its intended function,
it comes to the end of its life,
it has its own half-life.
Its death is a little bit more, you know,
regulated than our death is,
in that proteins are tagged with ubiquitin,
which leads to the recruitment by the proteasome,
and to their degradation.
So in order to target disease causing genes,
there are lots of different, you know,
modalities to go after them.
To target DNA,
There are gene therapies or CRISPr,
which is still in the works right now.
mRNA's, RNAi's are also things that are in development
and at the protein level,
there are small molecules and antibodies
that are also used.
However, what Craig talked about was something that used
kind of this last part of the protein's lifecycle
and looked at using ubiquitination
and proteasomal degradation as a possible therapy.
So, what he calls his tool is a PROTAC.
So PROteolysis Targeting Chimeras,
and they consist of a protein of interest targeting ligand,
a short chemical linker,
and an E3 ligase recruiting ligand,
which is essentially the degradation machinery
that allows for proteins to be ubiquitinated and degraded.
And PROTACs work by what we call event-driven pharmacology,
where they simply bring together the protein of interest
into close proximity with that E3 ligase,
which then allows for protein,
the protein to be ubiquitinated and degraded.
In addition, it's event-driven
because it's a catalytic process,
and that one small molecule,
or one small molecule PROTAC
can induce the ubiquitination and degradation
of more than one protein at a time.
One protein molecule at a time.
So once I learned about this technology,
I wanted to use it for difficult disease causing proteins.
And I worked on a number of different projects in the lab,
but the one that really took off
and ended up kind of being my PhD baby,
was my work on BRAF.
So BRAF is a kinase,
and what kinases do
is that they phosphorolate target proteins,
which is another type of post-translational modification.
And that leads to a number of downstream effects,
such as activation,
changes in the localization of a protein,
or even changing the different interaction partners
with proteins.
And these small, more localized effects
lead to different things, such as, you know,
inducing other proteins to be synthesized,
changing cell division, motility, growth,
or also changing, you know, your entire metabolism.
So BRAF is specifically a kinase
that is mutated in a number of cancers.
8% of all cancers.
The most common BRAF mutation is BRAF V600E.
So the valine mutated
and essentially causes an upregulation
of BRAF's kinase activity
leading to its activation and uncontrolled cell growth,
primarily in a number of cancers, including melanoma.
So essentially misregulation of BRAF is an issue.
However, due to its prevalence of V600E specifically,
there have been small molecule inhibitors
that have been developed.
Primarily the first one developed in 2011 is Vemurafenib.
And the way it works
is by occupancy driven pharmacology,
where it kind of takes the place of its normal substrate ATP
and inhibits the protein's function.
And small molecule inhibitors are really great therapies
and they worked really well for oncology,
but one issue with them, unfortunately,
is that resistance does form to them.
And in the case of Vemurafenib,
this occurs between six to eight months.
And mechanisms of resistance include upregulation
of the kinase itself,
things that completely bypass the kinase
and allow for the same function to occur
without using that kinase,
or additional mutations.
And these are acquired resistance mechanisms
to BRAF V600E.
And beyond that even, so beyond the V600E,
this one point mutation there,
as more cancers and tumors are being sequenced,
we've identified several more.
So there are two, a Class 2 BRAF inhibitors,
Two Class 2 BRAF.
A BRAF in Class 3, which are really interesting,
in that they're kinase dead.
But all these additional classes have also been shown
to drive different cancers.
And unfortunately,
Vemurafenib is intrinsically resistant to both of these.
So in general,
BRAF is a kinase and they are inhibitors
for one specific mutation,
but there really is a need for additional therapies
to target this.
And this is kind of where our project came in.
So, in collaboration with a really great,
really great chemist in the lab, Saul,
we synthesized and designed a number of different PROTACs.
I think we ended up designing about 30,
and this is our lead at the end,
which included Vemurafenib as our BRAF recruiting ligand,
a sharp chemical linker,
Pearson based linker,
and then the VHL ligand.
So the first thing we did was to evaluate our PROTACs
in fiberblast cells
that expressed a number of different mutations
that are, that had been seen in clinic.
And what we saw was that with treatment of our PROTAC,
we saw a dose dependent decrease in BRAF levels.
So degradation of the mutant BRAF,
which was really great.
But even more interesting was that our PROTAC
was able to spare wild type BRAF.
So we're able to selectively target
only the mutant form of the protein,
and completely spare the normal functioning protein,
which is really great
in terms of when you design a drug,
'cause you really want to increase that therapeutic index
and which decreases the chance of toxicity.
So we went on to test these in cancer cells
and saw similar results
in inhibition of the pathway.
And those results made us hopeful to test these in,
in a xenograph model in mice.
And we found that a 10 day treatment
caused a really nice tumor regression
in the cell line that is a Class 2 BRAF,
which is insensitive to Vemurafenib,
as I said before.
So in general here,
we're able to take essentially
a warhead that is insensitive
to one mutant and turn it into a PROTAC,
which is able to induce degradation
of something that has no therapy right now,
which was really wonderful to see.
And we did this in collaboration with the Rosen lab,
which were a great set of BRAF biologists to work with.
So in summary,
why are PROTACs so great,
and why was I so excited to work with them?
One, because of their catalytic mechanism of action,
they're able to target overexpressed,
proteins that are overexpressed.
So you don't have to use more drug
to overcome overexpression.
In addition,
you don't necessarily need something
to completely inhibit a protein.
You just kind of need a binder
to tag your proteins
in order to recruit them,
you know, or in order to induce degradation.
And in our projects,
we're able to show that.
We're able to selectively do this
with acquired and intrinsic resistance mechanisms to BRAF.
However of course,
things that completely bypass BRAF
we're unable to target.
In addition, PROTACs are really poised
to kind of,
and degraders in general,
are poised to expand kind of that druggable space.
So right now therapies, unfortunately,
only touch a small quarter of disease causing proteins,
and due to the mechanism of action,
if these were helpful,
that would be able to kind of tag these undruggable,
quote on quote proteins,
and induce degradation.
And that's kind of what I'm still excited about,
and what I'm still working on right now
at Monte Rosa Therapeutics,
but taking a slightly different path,
which is still in the same space.
So the way molecular glues work is that
they first bind your E3 ligase of interest.
And then only in the presence of these,
are you able to bind your disease causing protein
and induce similar proteasome-mediated degradation.
However, molecular glues tend to be smaller,
drug-like molecules,
and for that reason,
I thought to maybe be a little bit easier
in terms of getting accepted into the clinic.
And in addition, it doesn't need a druggable pocket
on your disease causing protein,
which also poises it to kind of touch,
to better reach undruggable proteins.
So with that, I would like to thank
everyone who has been on my journey
from Cornell, to the Schlessinger Lab, to the PREP program.
Everyone at the Crews lab who I interacted with,
it was a great, great learning experience.
My collaborators at the Rosen Lab,
my thesis committee,
and everyone at Monte Rosa,
Dom, Sharon, who work with me now.
And last but not least, of course,
I'd like to thank my family
and my partner Bomboy
for being a huge support system to me,
and helping me reach where I am today.
With that, I'll take any questions.
Thank you so much Shanique.
I was wondering what,
what happened to your PROTAC?
what are the next steps for it?
The one you developed.
So, unfortunately I'm no longer in the lab,
but I know that I hear that, like, you know,
we still have interest in trying
a couple of different cancer types
that we didn't necessarily touch on
in my project.
So that's definitely ongoing right now.
Yeah, in the lab.
Okay.
Thank you so much.
